title: Introducing pataqu
text: chiefly mind archaeological data dating remains often temporally bounded two certain events, named terminus post/ante quem, abbreviated tpq taq1. tpq earliest date, taq latest. real event may happened anytime two boundaries flat, uniform, density probability along interval. can also think radiocarbon dating, comes prediction confidence interval (say \(\mu ± \sigma\)). dating differ real event density probability gaussian nature parameters \(\mu\) \(\sigma\).

what: Consequences and how to inspect them
title: Introducing pataqu
text: Whatever source uncertainty, graphics, tests overall stories can obtain data may well affected. robust lovely trends temporal uncertainties? pataqu aims visualizing testing using permutations. way view merit use information contained data . idea : Simulate plausible new x values Display /test need Repeat many times see happens

title: Introducing pataqu
text: load package also use dplyr ggplot2 tidyverse. Overall, library(tidyverse) need much more2
code: library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(pataqu)

title: Introducing pataqu
text: dataset made real (unpublished) data researchers measured value interest archaeological remains, several sites (us stratigraphical units ), dated tpq taq. remains belonged four taxa. treat ? decide display full interval see happens:  mess! try add mid point add smoother top . now able see trends lost uncertainty x meantime. graph may also one , likelihood. take animals simply draw x_new values, midpoint, somewhere tpq taq line. use set.seed sake replicability .  different. code used exactly shake_uniform made behind curtain3. pataqu generalizes idea little decoration around pattern. mother function simulate 5 new datasets randomized datations. true dates can anytime ptq taq. use quake_uniform. Let’s look results: One can now test globally patterns taxa differ: also test pairwise differences: can also check differ:
code: head(animals) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   taxa  site   us        tpq   taq   value #>   <fct> <chr>  <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 frog  Alz-Br A-B_FO   -125   -50 -0.0352 #> 2 frog  Ans-lM A-M_12     50   700 -0.123  #> 3 frog  Ans-lM A-M_12     50   700 -0.129  #> 4 frog  Ans-lM A-M_139   150   200  0.120  #> 5 frog  Ans-lM An-M_15    50   700  0.0575 #> 6 frog  Ans-lM A-M_150    50   200  0.0528 # We only show the first lines but you can View(animals) # pure cosmetics for lighter graphs theme_set(theme_minimal())  animals %>% ggplot() +  geom_errorbarh(aes(xmin=tpq, xmax=taq, y=value, col=taxa), size=0.2, alpha=0.5) animals %>%    mutate(x_new=(tpq+taq)/2) %>%    ggplot() +  aes(x=x_new, y=value, col=taxa) +  geom_point(size=0.1) +  geom_smooth(method="loess", formula="y~x", se=FALSE) -> gg_mid gg_mid set.seed(2329) # lets draw new x values animals2 <- animals %>%     dplyr::rowwise() %>%     dplyr::mutate(x_new=stats::runif(n=1, min=tpq, max=taq)) %>%     dplyr::ungroup() # and redo gg_mid graph with this new tibble gg_mid %+% animals2 a_q <- animals %>%    quake_uniform(tpq, taq, value, k=5, group=taxa) #>  * working on a temporal sequence of 30 steps #>  * launching 5 permutations a_q #> # A tibble: 600 × 4 #>        k group   x_new        y #>    <int> <chr>   <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1     1 cat   -225    -0.184   #>  2     1 cat   -193.   -0.167   #>  3     1 cat   -161.   -0.148   #>  4     1 cat   -129.   -0.128   #>  5     1 cat    -97.4  -0.106   #>  6     1 cat    -65.5  -0.0822  #>  7     1 cat    -33.6  -0.0571  #>  8     1 cat     -1.72 -0.0310  #>  9     1 cat     30.2  -0.00412 #> 10     1 cat     62.1   0.0225  #> # … with 590 more rows spaghetti(a_q) res_global <- a_q %>% synchrony() #>  * testing on 30 temporal slices #>  * testing pairwise differences using kruskal_p res_global %>% filter(p<1e-4) #> # A tibble: 0 × 2 #> # … with 2 variables: x_new <dbl>, p <dbl> res <- a_q %>% synchrony_pw() #>  * testing on 30 temporal slices #>  * testing global differences using wilcox_p head(res) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   x_new pw                 p #>   <dbl> <chr>          <dbl> #> 1  -225 bird ~ cat   0.00794 #> 2  -225 bird ~ frog  0.0317  #> 3  -225 bird ~ mouse 0.00794 #> 4  -225 cat ~ frog   0.00794 #> 5  -225 cat ~ mouse  0.00794 #> 6  -225 frog ~ mouse 0.00794 res %>% filter(p<0.0001) #> # A tibble: 0 × 3 #> # … with 3 variables: x_new <dbl>, pw <chr>, p <dbl>

text: Bonhomme V, Evin (2022). pataqu: Permutationnal Analysis Terminus Ante post QUem data. https://github.com/vbonhomme/pataqu, https://vbonhomme.github.io/pataqu/.

what: Permutationnal Analysis of Terminus Ante and post QUem data
title: Permutationnal Analysis of Terminus Ante and post QUem data
text: pataqu uses permutationnal approach deal data comes uncertainties x. typically aimed working temporal data exactly defined comes lower (upper) bounds, also called terminus ante (post) quem. can also used dating, typically radiocarbon dating, comes confidence interval likely affect interpretation. generally, permutationnal approach allows inspect graphically statistically effects x uncertainties.

title: Permutationnal Analysis of Terminus Ante and post QUem data
text: can install development version pataqu GitHub : latest version released CRAN :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("vbonhomme/pataqu") install.packages("pataqu")

title: Permutationnal Analysis of Terminus Ante and post QUem data
text: Let’s say measure value interest archaeological animal remains. remains recovered sites dated terminus ante post quem. sites, find several species like test : effect temporal uncertainties affect temporal trend species pairs differ first load pataqu look animals dataset Let’s visualize happens decide take midpoint tpq taq display temporal trend species:  mess! still, take account uncertainties dating, reason today. realistic view something like: comes pataqu. simulate 5 new datasets randomized datations. true dates can anytime ptq taq. use quake_uniform. Let’s look results: One can now test globally patterns taxa differ: also test pairwise differences: can also check differ:
code: library(pataqu) head(animals) #>   taxa   site      us  tpq taq       value #> 1 frog Alz-Br  A-B_FO -125 -50 -0.03521491 #> 2 frog Ans-lM  A-M_12   50 700 -0.12260232 #> 3 frog Ans-lM  A-M_12   50 700 -0.12933662 #> 4 frog Ans-lM A-M_139  150 200  0.11962616 #> 5 frog Ans-lM An-M_15   50 700  0.05752877 #> 6 frog Ans-lM A-M_150   50 200  0.05275057 # We only show the first lines but you can View(animals) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2)  # create the mid point animals_mid <-  mutate(animals, x=(tpq + taq)/2) head(animals_mid) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   taxa  site   us        tpq   taq   value     x #>   <fct> <chr>  <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 frog  Alz-Br A-B_FO   -125   -50 -0.0352 -87.5 #> 2 frog  Ans-lM A-M_12     50   700 -0.123  375   #> 3 frog  Ans-lM A-M_12     50   700 -0.129  375   #> 4 frog  Ans-lM A-M_139   150   200  0.120  175   #> 5 frog  Ans-lM An-M_15    50   700  0.0575 375   #> 6 frog  Ans-lM A-M_150    50   200  0.0528 125  # visualize with a loess ggplot(animals_mid) +  aes(x=x, y=value, col=taxa) +  geom_point(size=0.1) +  geom_smooth(method="loess", formula="y~x", se=FALSE) +  theme_minimal() ggplot(animals_mid) +  aes(x=x, y=value, col=taxa) +  geom_errorbarh(aes(xmin=tpq, xmax=taq)) +  geom_point(size=0.1) +  geom_smooth(method="loess", formula="y~x", se=FALSE) +  theme_minimal() a_q <- animals %>%    quake_uniform(tpq, taq, value, k=5, group=taxa) #>  * working on a temporal sequence of 30 steps #>  * launching 5 permutations a_q #> # A tibble: 600 × 4 #>        k group   x_new        y #>    <int> <chr>   <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1     1 cat   -225    -0.180   #>  2     1 cat   -193.   -0.165   #>  3     1 cat   -161.   -0.148   #>  4     1 cat   -129.   -0.129   #>  5     1 cat    -97.4  -0.107   #>  6     1 cat    -65.5  -0.0838  #>  7     1 cat    -33.6  -0.0583  #>  8     1 cat     -1.72 -0.0316  #>  9     1 cat     30.2  -0.00476 #> 10     1 cat     62.1   0.0247  #> # … with 590 more rows spaghetti(a_q) res_global <- a_q %>% synchrony() #>  * testing on 30 temporal slices #>  * testing pairwise differences using kruskal_p res_global %>% filter(p<1e-4) #> # A tibble: 0 × 2 #> # … with 2 variables: x_new <dbl>, p <dbl> res <- a_q %>% synchrony_pw() #>  * testing on 30 temporal slices #>  * testing global differences using wilcox_p head(res) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   x_new pw                 p #>   <dbl> <chr>          <dbl> #> 1  -225 bird ~ cat   0.00794 #> 2  -225 bird ~ frog  0.151   #> 3  -225 bird ~ mouse 0.00794 #> 4  -225 cat ~ frog   0.00794 #> 5  -225 cat ~ mouse  0.00794 #> 6  -225 frog ~ mouse 0.00794 res %>% filter(p<0.0001) #> # A tibble: 0 × 3 #> # … with 3 variables: x_new <dbl>, pw <chr>, p <dbl>

what: Animals with 20 permutations on 7 temporal slices — animals_q

text: See animals. obtained :
code: set.seed(2329) animals_q <-  quake_uniform(animals, tpq, taq, value, k=20, group=taxa) %>%   dplyr::filter(x_new < 100, x_new > -100)

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: See magrittr::%>% details.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
code: lhs %>% rhs

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: lhs value magrittr placeholder. rhs function call using magrittr semantics.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: result calling rhs(lhs).

what: Predictor function to summarise results after shaking — predictor
title: Predictor function to summarise results after shaking — predictor
text: functions used internally quake_ synchrony_ functions, may interest custom constructions. See Details.

title: Predictor function to summarise results after shaking — predictor
code: predictor_loess(df, x_prediction, ...)  predictor_gam(df, x_prediction, ...)  predictor_lm(df, x_prediction, ...)  predictor_bins_breaks(df, x_prediction, ...)  predictor_bins_midpoint(df, x_prediction, ...)  predictor_none(df, ...)

title: Predictor function to summarise results after shaking — predictor
text: df tibble(), typically shake. Must .x .y columns. x_prediction numeric vector x values predict ... additional parameters predictors (see Details)

title: Predictor function to summarise results after shaking — predictor
text: df, x_new y columns must present. ease fasten permutations raw data prepared . functions thin wrappers around built- predictors stats::loess(), stats::lm(), mgcv::gam(), etc. predictors follow steps: fit y (value interest) using (typically shaken) x. thus obtain continuous model use : predict new y values range x. x values typically fixed, can later obtain confidence intervals, etc. points. thus aim summarising new y values fixed x values, using predict_bin makes intermediate adjustment summarises raw value either using mean median (see Examples) predict_none just passes shaken values adjustment

title: Predictor function to summarise results after shaking — predictor
text: predictor_loess: predict using stats::loess() predictor_gam: predict using mgcv::gam predictor_lm: predict using stats::lm() predictor_bins_breaks: fit, just cut() returns slices factor predictor_bins_midpoint: fit, just cut() returns slices numeric predictor_none: fit, just pass raw values

title: Predictor function to summarise results after shaking — predictor
code: # replicability set.seed(2329) x_pred <- 1:100 df <- tibble::tibble(x_new=x_pred, y=runif(100, -1, 1) + x_pred/100) x_pred <- 1:100 p_loess  <- predictor_loess(df, x_pred) # default span, ie 0.75 p_loess2 <- predictor_loess(df, x_pred, span=0.2) # custom span  # or using gam instead p_gam <- predictor_gam(df, x_pred) # or lm p_lm  <- predictor_lm(df, x_pred)  plot(df$x_new, df$y) lines(p_loess$x_new, p_loess$y, col="firebrick3") lines(p_loess2$x_new, p_loess2$y, col="orange") lines(p_gam$x_new, p_gam$y, col="blue") lines(p_lm$x_new, p_lm$y, col="forestgreen")   ### bins # when using bins the output depends of the function p_breaks <- predictor_bins_breaks(df, x_pred) # this returns factors p_breaks #> # A tibble: 100 × 2 #>    x_new        y #>    <fct>    <dbl> #>  1 [1,2]   0.353  #>  2 [1,2]  -0.878  #>  3 (2,3]   0.895  #>  4 (3,4]   0.0941 #>  5 (4,5]  -0.902  #>  6 (5,6]   0.482  #>  7 (6,7]   0.170  #>  8 (7,8]   0.352  #>  9 (8,9]  -0.752  #> 10 (9,10]  0.820  #> # … with 90 more rows # and their natural graphical output is a boxplot p_breaks %>% boxplot(y~x_new, data=.)   # but this one returns midpoint as a numeric p_midpoint <- predictor_bins_midpoint(df, x_pred) # and the binning is quite clear here plot(df$x_new, df$y) points(p_midpoint$x_new, p_midpoint$y, col="blue", pch=20)   # should you just want raw shaken values p_none <- predictor_none(df) plot(df$x_new, df$y, col="red", pch=20) points(p_none$x_new, p_none$y, col="blue", pch=3)

what: Use permutations to visualize and test uncertainties on x — quake_uniform
title: Use permutations to visualize and test uncertainties on x — quake_uniform
text: details .

title: Use permutations to visualize and test uncertainties on x — quake_uniform
code: quake_uniform(   df,   tpq,   taq,   y,   group,   k = 10,   predictor_fun = predictor_loess,   x_prediction = 30,   ... )

title: Use permutations to visualize and test uncertainties on x — quake_uniform
text: df data.frame() work tpq, taq colname use tpq taq (shaking_gaussian) y colname use value interest group colname (optionnal) whether groups k number permutations (10 default) predictor_fun function one predictor x_prediction predict new values. See Details. ... additional arguments predictor_fun

title: Use permutations to visualize and test uncertainties on x — quake_uniform
text: x_prediction can passed single numeric vector numeric. single numeric passed, regular sequence length created min(tpq) max(taq), ie covering full temporal span. vector numeric passed, values used. default, eis 30, 30 dates covering temporal span used. See examples.

title: Use permutations to visualize and test uncertainties on x — quake_uniform
code: set.seed(2329) # for replicability  # let's say animals had different names x <- animals %>% dplyr::rename(post=tpq, ante=taq, lsi=value) x #> # A tibble: 5,533 × 6 #>    taxa  site   us        post  ante      lsi #>    <fct> <chr>  <chr>    <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1 frog  Alz-Br A-B_FO    -125   -50 -0.0352  #>  2 frog  Ans-lM A-M_12      50   700 -0.123   #>  3 frog  Ans-lM A-M_12      50   700 -0.129   #>  4 frog  Ans-lM A-M_139    150   200  0.120   #>  5 frog  Ans-lM An-M_15     50   700  0.0575  #>  6 frog  Ans-lM A-M_150     50   200  0.0528  #>  7 frog  Ans-lM A-M_150     50   200 -0.00804 #>  8 frog  Arl-Cp A-C_1061   -75   -40 -0.0760  #>  9 frog  Arl-Cp A-C_4043   -40   -15 -0.00385 #> 10 frog  Arl-Cp A-C_7039   -15    60 -0.0608  #> # … with 5,523 more rows x %>% quake_uniform(post, ante, lsi) #>  * working on a temporal sequence of 30 steps #>  * launching 10 permutations #> # A tibble: 300 × 3 #>        k   x_new        y #>    <int>   <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1     1 -225    -0.132   #>  2     1 -193.   -0.112   #>  3     1 -161.   -0.0931  #>  4     1 -129.   -0.0751  #>  5     1  -97.4  -0.0582  #>  6     1  -65.5  -0.0424  #>  7     1  -33.6  -0.0280  #>  8     1   -1.72 -0.0146  #>  9     1   30.2  -0.00189 #> 10     1   62.1   0.00789 #> # … with 290 more rows  animals %>% quake_uniform(tpq, taq, value, k=2, group=taxa) #>  * working on a temporal sequence of 30 steps #>  * launching 2 permutations #> # A tibble: 240 × 4 #>        k group   x_new        y #>    <int> <chr>   <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1     1 cat   -225    -0.165   #>  2     1 cat   -193.   -0.155   #>  3     1 cat   -161.   -0.142   #>  4     1 cat   -129.   -0.126   #>  5     1 cat    -97.4  -0.106   #>  6     1 cat    -65.5  -0.0837  #>  7     1 cat    -33.6  -0.0587  #>  8     1 cat     -1.72 -0.0323  #>  9     1 cat     30.2  -0.00544 #> 10     1 cat     62.1   0.0225  #> # … with 230 more rows  if (FALSE) { library(ggplot2) x %>% ggplot() +   aes(x_new, y, group=k, col=group) +   geom_point(size=0.3) +   theme_minimal() +  geom_smooth(aes(group=NULL, col=group)) }

title: Generate new x values — shake
text: Used internally permutation generate new x values. Different shakers available depending type uncertainties .

title: Generate new x values — shake
code: shake_uniform(x)  shake_gaussian(x)

title: Generate new x values — shake
text: x tibble() typically obtained permutations

title: Generate new x values — shake
text: 'shaked'  tibble()

title: Generate new x values — shake
text: expects tpq, taq colnames shake_uniform, mean, sd shake_gaussian

title: Generate new x values — shake
text: shake_uniform: uniform distribution shake_gaussian: gaussian distribution

title: Generate new x values — shake
code: set.seed(2329) # replicability tibble::tibble(tpq=c(-50, 100), taq=c(50, 200)) %>% shake_uniform() #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>     tpq   taq x_new #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1   -50    50  17.2 #> 2   100   200 105.  tibble::tibble(mean=c(0, 100), sd=c(5, 20)) %>% shake_gaussian() #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>    mean    sd x_new #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     0     5  7.48 #> 2   100    20 60.4

title: Spaghetti plot after permutations — spaghetti
text: ggplot2 primer result quake displaying results permutations. allows inspecting effect predictors.

title: Spaghetti plot after permutations — spaghetti
code: spaghetti(x, ...)

title: Spaghetti plot after permutations — spaghetti
text: x result permutation function ... additional parameters ggplot2::geom_line()

title: Spaghetti plot after permutations — spaghetti
code: animals_q %>% spaghetti()   # you can easily customize it # color palette from https://www.colourlovers.com/palette/1473/Ocean_Five colors <- c("bird"="#00A0B0","cat"="#CC333F", "frog"="#CBE86B", "mouse"="#EDC951") library(ggplot2) animals_q %>% spaghetti(alpha=0.5, size=0.1) +   scale_color_manual(values=colors) +   xlab("year") + ylab("value of interest") +   guides(colour=guide_legend("taxa", override.aes=list(alpha=1, size=2)))

what: Test differences within temporal slices — synchrony
title: Test differences within temporal slices — synchrony
text: Useful quake() test "synchronic" differences groups. Within temporal unit :

title: Test differences within temporal slices — synchrony
code: synchrony(df, x = x_new, y = y, group = group, test_fun = kruskal_p)  synchrony_pw(df, x = x_new, y = y, group = group, test_fun = wilcox_p)

title: Test differences within temporal slices — synchrony
text: df tibble() typically result quake() x, y, group colnames use test_fun function pick among synchrony_testers(). default kruskal_p/wilcox_p synchrony/synchrony_pw, respectively.

title: Test differences within temporal slices — synchrony
text: synchrony test least one group differs others synchrony_pw test pairwise differences groups present time.

title: Test differences within temporal slices — synchrony
code: (an1 <- animals_q %>% synchrony()) #>  * testing on 7 temporal slices #>  * testing pairwise differences using kruskal_p #> # A tibble: 7 × 2 #>    x_new        p #>    <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1 -97.4  7.89e-16 #> 2 -65.5  5.72e-16 #> 3 -33.6  1.44e-15 #> 4  -1.72 5.72e-16 #> 5  30.2  2.66e-14 #> 6  62.1  9.06e-16 #> 7  94.0  1.25e-15 # pairwise testing and using aov here (an2 <- animals_q %>% synchrony_pw(test_fun=aov_p)) #>  * testing on 7 temporal slices #>  * testing global differences using aov_p #> # A tibble: 42 × 3 #>    x_new pw                  p #>    <dbl> <chr>           <dbl> #>  1 -97.4 bird ~ cat   5.35e-49 #>  2 -97.4 bird ~ frog  7.14e-10 #>  3 -97.4 bird ~ mouse 1.12e-28 #>  4 -97.4 cat ~ frog   7.10e-50 #>  5 -97.4 cat ~ mouse  9.80e-63 #>  6 -97.4 frog ~ mouse 7.95e-36 #>  7 -65.5 bird ~ cat   2.29e-53 #>  8 -65.5 bird ~ frog  1.61e-28 #>  9 -65.5 bird ~ mouse 4.69e-20 #> 10 -65.5 cat ~ frog   1.13e-53 #> # … with 32 more rows  # you can easily filter where it differs with alpha=1e-3 alpha_adj <- alpha/nrow(an1) # cheap Bonferroni correction an1 %>% dplyr::filter(p < alpha_adj) #> # A tibble: 7 × 2 #>    x_new        p #>    <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1 -97.4  7.89e-16 #> 2 -65.5  5.72e-16 #> 3 -33.6  1.44e-15 #> 4  -1.72 5.72e-16 #> 5  30.2  2.66e-14 #> 6  62.1  9.06e-16 #> 7  94.0  1.25e-15  # you can also easily recreate group columns tidyr::separate(an2, col=pw, into=c("group1", "group2"), sep=" ~ ", remove=FALSE) #> # A tibble: 42 × 5 #>    x_new pw           group1 group2        p #>    <dbl> <chr>        <chr>  <chr>     <dbl> #>  1 -97.4 bird ~ cat   bird   cat    5.35e-49 #>  2 -97.4 bird ~ frog  bird   frog   7.14e-10 #>  3 -97.4 bird ~ mouse bird   mouse  1.12e-28 #>  4 -97.4 cat ~ frog   cat    frog   7.10e-50 #>  5 -97.4 cat ~ mouse  cat    mouse  9.80e-63 #>  6 -97.4 frog ~ mouse frog   mouse  7.95e-36 #>  7 -65.5 bird ~ cat   bird   cat    2.29e-53 #>  8 -65.5 bird ~ frog  bird   frog   1.61e-28 #>  9 -65.5 bird ~ mouse bird   mouse  4.69e-20 #> 10 -65.5 cat ~ frog   cat    frog   1.13e-53 #> # … with 32 more rows  # if your tibble have different names just mention them animals_q %>%   # rename to simulate different names   dplyr::rename(taxa=group, year=x_new, value=y) %>%   # you retain your names   synchrony(year, value, taxa) #>  * testing on 7 temporal slices #>  * testing pairwise differences using kruskal_p #> # A tibble: 7 × 2 #>     year        p #>    <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1 -97.4  7.89e-16 #> 2 -65.5  5.72e-16 #> 3 -33.6  1.44e-15 #> 4  -1.72 5.72e-16 #> 5  30.2  2.66e-14 #> 6  62.1  9.06e-16 #> 7  94.0  1.25e-15

title: Pairwise comparisons testers — synchrony_testers
text: testers return p-value synchrony() pairwise comparisons.

title: Pairwise comparisons testers — synchrony_testers
code: wilcox_p(x)  kruskal_p(x)  aov_p(x)

title: Pairwise comparisons testers — synchrony_testers
text: x tibble() two columns named group y, two levels group.

title: Pairwise comparisons testers — synchrony_testers
text: numeric p.value (NA_real enough data groups)

title: Pairwise comparisons testers — synchrony_testers
text: testers thin wrappers around stats::wilcox.test, stats::kruskal.test stats::aov. Type wilcox_p (bracket) build .

title: Pairwise comparisons testers — synchrony_testers
text: wilcox_p: wilcoxon's rank test pairwise differences kruskal_p: kruskal's test global differences aov_p: analysis variance test global pairwise differences

title: Pairwise comparisons testers — synchrony_testers
code: # dummy tibble x <- tibble::tibble(group=rep(letters[1:2], each=10),                    y=stats::runif(20, -1, 1))  wilcox_p(x) #> [1] 0.9117972 aov_p(x) #> [1] 0.6966822  # on >2 groups x$group[15:20] <- "c" kruskal_p(x) #> [1] 0.5973583 aov_p(x) #> [1] 0.6072262

title: Tidy eval helpers — tidyeval
text: page lists tidy eval tools reexported package rlang. learn using tidy eval scripts packages high level, see dplyr programming vignette ggplot2 packages vignette. Metaprogramming section Advanced R may also useful deeper dive. tidy eval operators {{, !!, !!! syntactic constructs specially interpreted tidy eval functions. mostly need {{, !! !!! advanced operators use simple cases. curly-curly operator {{ allows tunnel data-variables passed function arguments inside tidy eval functions. {{ designed individual arguments. pass multiple arguments contained dots, use ... normal way. enquo() enquos() delay execution one several function arguments. former returns single expression, latter returns list expressions. defused, expressions longer evaluate . must injected back evaluation context !! (single expression) !!! (list expressions). simple case, code equivalent usage {{ ... . Defusing enquo() enquos() needed complex cases, instance need inspect modify expressions way. .data pronoun object represents current slice data. variable name string, use .data pronoun subset variable [[. Another tidy eval operator :=. makes possible use glue curly-curly syntax LHS =. technical reasons, R language support complex expressions left =, use := workaround. Many tidy eval functions like dplyr::mutate() dplyr::summarise() give automatic name unnamed inputs. need create sort automatic names , use as_label(). instance, glue-tunnelling syntax can reproduced manually : Expressions defused enquo() (tunnelled {{) need simple column names, can arbitrarily complex. as_label() handles cases gracefully. code assumes simple column name, use as_name() instead. safer throws error input name expected.
code: my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   data %>%     group_by(...) %>%     summarise(mean = mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   # Defuse   var <- enquo(var)   dots <- enquos(...)    # Inject   data %>%     group_by(!!!dots) %>%     summarise(mean = mean(!!var)) } my_var <- "disp" mtcars %>% summarise(mean = mean(.data[[my_var]])) my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   # Use `{{` to tunnel function arguments and the usual glue   # operator `{` to interpolate plain strings.   data %>%     summarise("{{ var }}_mean_{suffix}" := mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   var <- enquo(var)   prefix <- as_label(var)   data %>%     summarise("{prefix}_mean_{suffix}" := mean(!!var)) }
